name: specialize
content:
specialize verb [I]
(SPECIAL SKILL, PRODUCT, ETC.)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B2 to study or work on a particular subject or skill more than any others, so that you become an expert in it: She hired a lawyer who specializes in divorce cases. I enjoy working in general medicine, but I hope to be able to specialize in the future.
to offer a particular product or service more than any other, usually so that you have a good reputation for this product or service: a restaurant that specializes in seafood
to do something very often, so that you are known for doing it: Their home fans specialize in personal taunts that often cross the line into abuse.
More examplesFewer examplesThese nurses specialize in the care of the dying.Some people argue that 18-year-olds are too young to specialize, and that such a narrow educational scope prevents them from exploring diverse fields at their own pace.Consider seeing a counsellor who specializes in stepfamily relationships.US marshals specialize in finding fugitives and escapees.The company specializes in customized computer systems.This store specializes in natural-fibre wallpapers inspired by kimonos and woodblock paintings. She specializes in historical novels set in 18th-century England.He specializes in breeding large dogs such as Irish wolfhounds.

specialize verb [I]
(IN BIOLOGY)
biology
  specialized to change or develop in order to suit a particular environment or situation, or to perform a particular function: Embryonic stem cells begin to specialize and move through the body to develop organs such as the heart, bones and skin. Some insects are general pollinators, and others specialize. See also
specialized
More examplesFewer examplesTo keep stem cells from specializing requires a carefully controlled lab environment.The precursor cells are able to proliferate (continue to replicate) and specialize into different functions.Adult cells have a more limited ability to specialize than embryonic cells.
